title: Chapter 1 – UK Group Risk Market (Original MCQs)

questions.stem: What is the primary advantage for an employer of insuring group risk benefits rather than self‑insuring them?
options: It guarantees a lower premium than the expected cost of claims.
It transfers low‑frequency, high‑severity claim volatility to the insurer’s pool.
It removes all administrative responsibilities from the employer.
It ensures employees never need to provide medical evidence.
questions.explanation: Insurance pools catastrophic risk and smooths costs; admin responsibilities may remain and medical evidence can still be required above thresholds.

questions.stem: Which participant typically designs scheme benefits, tenders to insurers, and manages ongoing governance on behalf of the employer?
options: The reinsurer
The intermediary/consultant
The trustee bank
The payroll provider
questions.explanation: Intermediaries (brokers/consultants) advise on design, run market exercises, and support governance.

questions.stem: A large multinational wants oversight of several country schemes and potential dividends when claims are favourable. Which structure best matches this aim?
options: Unit‑rating
Experience‑rating
Multinational pooling
Co‑insurance
questions.explanation: Multinational pooling aggregates results across countries and may return a dividend if experience is good.

questions.stem: Which factor is MOST likely to improve a quoted unit rate for a GLA scheme at renewal?
options: Worsening occupation risk mix
High claims versus expected in the last year
Accurate, timely membership and salary data
Increasing the benefit multiple from 3× to 4×
questions.explanation: Clean data reduces uncertainty and back‑billing; adverse occupation mix and higher multiples tend to increase cost.

questions.stem: Which statement about self‑insurance is MOST accurate?
options: It eliminates volatility for the employer.
It is illegal for employee benefits in the UK.
It can reduce cost if claims are favourable but exposes the employer to variability.
It guarantees faster claims payment than insured arrangements.
questions.explanation: Self‑insurance may save cost but retains volatility; insured arrangements transfer risk to the insurer’s pool.

questions.stem: Which best describes a hybrid approach used by some large corporates for group risk benefits?
options: Fully pooled unit rate with no experience consideration
Captive or experience‑rated base with stop‑loss/catastrophe cover
Individual underwriting for every member below FCL
Co‑payment by employees at the point of claim
questions.explanation: Hybrids often retain day‑to‑day risk (experience‑rated/captive) but buy stop‑loss to cap tail risk.

questions.stem: Why do intermediaries focus heavily on data quality (eligibility, salaries, joiners/leavers) when marketing a scheme?
options: It reduces insurer reinsurance costs directly.
It ensures consistent unit rates across all insurers regardless of risk.
It improves underwriting confidence, speeds quotes, and supports sharper pricing.
It removes the need for any medical evidence.
questions.explanation: Good data improves risk assessment and quoting efficiency, often leading to better terms.

questions.stem: Which market condition would MOST likely push rates upward for group risk insurers?
options: Improving mortality trends
Increased reinsurance capacity
Claims inflation and worsening experience
Higher data granularity from employers
questions.explanation: Claims inflation and worse‑than‑expected experience put upward pressure on pricing.

questions.stem: Which stakeholder primarily seeks analytics and regular experience reviews to steer benefit design changes over time?
options: Employees
Large corporate employers
Trust beneficiaries
Payroll providers
questions.explanation: Large corporates often request MI dashboards and experience reviews to manage cost and design.

questions.stem: Which of the following is LEAST aligned with the role of a reinsurer in the group risk market?
options: Providing catastrophe protection to insurers
Accepting facultative placements for very large sums assured
Running payroll and issuing trust documentation for employers
Supporting pricing stability and capacity
questions.explanation: Payroll and trust paperwork sit with employer/admin; reinsurers support capacity, protection, and pricing stability.

questions.stem: A scheme moves from unit‑rated to experience‑rated terms. Which change is MOST consistent with this decision?
options: Scheme has grown and now has credible claims history.
Employer wants to remove all exposure to volatility.
Market has reduced reinsurance capacity.
Employees are moving into lower‑risk occupations.
questions.explanation: Experience‑rating becomes viable as scheme size and credible history grow; it doesn’t remove volatility entirely.

questions.stem: Which communication is MOST important for employees under a GLA scheme?
options: How to complete and update nomination/expressions of wish
How to underwrite above the FCL for other members
How to calculate reinsurer capital requirements
How to run a multinational pooling dividend calculation
questions.explanation: Clear nomination guidance helps ensure trustees can make timely, appropriate decisions.
